childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1995-2007

Children born in 1995 arrived in the same year as the Oklahoma City bombing — 168 people killed, including 19 children in a daycare on the second floor of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building. The photograph of a firefighter carrying an infant became the decade's most searing image. This cohort was too young to know any of it, but the bombing reshaped the security landscape of the country they'd grow up in. Federal buildings were fortified. Concrete barriers appeared in front of government offices. The idea that an American could commit mass murder on American soil was no longer theoretical.

Their early childhood overlapped with the final years of the Clinton administration and the last stretch of the 1990s economic boom. The dot-com bubble was inflating. Families were buying computers. The evening news alternated between the president's impeachment and breathless reports about the internet. For small children, none of this registered as anything more than background noise — adults talking, the television on, the hum of a household going about its business. The prosperity of the era showed up in small ways: a bigger house, a second car, a vacation that lasted a full week instead of a long weekend.

At six, the world changed. September 11, 2001, found this cohort in first grade — old enough to sense that something terrible had happened, young enough that the adults around them struggled with how much to explain. Some schools turned on televisions. Others sent children home. Either way, the atmosphere shifted instantly and permanently. The remaining seven years of their childhood would unfold entirely in the post-9/11 world: a country at war, a surveillance apparatus expanding, a national mood defined by a low-frequency anxiety that never fully dissipated, even when the threat level dropped from orange back to yellow.

By the time this cohort was in third grade, the Iraq War had begun. By fifth grade, Hurricane Katrina had exposed the government's inability to protect its own citizens. The childhood that followed was shaped by these overlapping crises — not as events children analyzed, but as the texture of daily life. Troops deploying from their communities. Support the Troops magnets on every other car. Security lines at every public event. The school lockdown drill, practiced with increasing frequency and seriousness, teaching children to be quiet, to hide, to wait. Safety was no longer assumed. It was rehearsed.

The domestic atmosphere of their late childhood — ages ten through twelve — was marked by a growing unease that adults tried to keep from the dinner table but couldn't. Gas prices were climbing. Housing prices were doing something strange — rising fast in some places, stalling in others. Their parents might have refinanced the mortgage or talked about the market in tones that mixed excitement with nervousness. The 2008 financial crisis would arrive when this cohort was thirteen, officially ending their childhood and beginning an adolescence defined by economic anxiety. But the warning signs were there years earlier, visible in the tightening of household budgets, in the hesitation before purchases that used to be automatic, in the slow erosion of the certainty that had defined their earliest years.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996. This cohort is at the very end of that range, which means they have more in common with older Gen Z than with elder Millennials born in the early '80s. Some researchers call this micro-generation 'Zillennials'—old enough to remember life before smartphones, young enough to have grown up on social media.

The Millennial generation numbers roughly 72 million people in the US, making it the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. This cohort is part of the demographic wave that marketers obsessed over, think pieces pathologized, and employers exploited while calling it opportunity.

9/11 is still this generation's defining moment, even though this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}. They don't remember the before times as clearly as older Millennials do—they were too young—but they grew up entirely in the after times. The security theater, the endless wars, the ambient anxiety that adults couldn't quite hide—that was just normal for them.

This cohort graduated high school in 2013, which meant they missed the worst of the 2008 job market but inherited all its consequences. The 2008 crisis shaped their expectations—they were {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}} when Lehman Brothers collapsed. College was more expensive than ever. Entry-level jobs demanded experience they couldn't get without entry-level jobs. The economy 'recovered' in ways that mainly benefited people who already had wealth.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. This generation gets blamed for killing industries, but mostly they just can't afford what older generations took for granted. They didn't kill homeownership—they got priced out. They didn't kill diamonds—they're paying off student loans. They didn't kill Applebee's—they can't afford to eat out when rent takes 40% of their income. The accusations of entitlement are particularly rich coming from generations that had pensions and affordable housing and job security.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1995 brought Toy Story coming out—the first fully computer-animated feature film. That feels metaphorically appropriate. This generation watched animation evolve from hand-drawn to digital, saw special effects go from practical to CGI, experienced the entire media landscape transform from physical objects to streaming data.

1995 was peak '90s. Coolio's 'Gangsta's Paradise' dominated the radio with its earnest intensity. Alanis Morissette was telling everyone what irony wasn't (while ironically getting irony wrong, which is arguably ironic). TLC was warning about waterfalls. Clueless defined a generation's vocabulary and made Beverly Hills seem aspirational. Batman Forever proved franchises could be ruined with neon and nipples.

This childhood was the Disney Renaissance's last gasp and the early Pixar era. Watching Pocahontas and Hercules in theaters—the later, lesser Renaissance films. Wearing out VHS tapes of The Lion King. By the time this cohort was old enough to have critical opinions, Shrek was making fun of everything Disney had taught them to love.

Middle school years belonged to emo music, MySpace profile customization, and the rise of YouTube. Probably having a screen name they're now embarrassed by and away messages on AIM that were really just poetry for a crush. High school years were the early iPhone era, the Obama era, the beginning of streaming destroying cable TV.

This cohort is the last generation to remember renting movies from Blockbuster, to experience the communal anticipation of a TV show airing once a week, to understand why 'Be Kind, Rewind' mattered. Also young enough that binge-watching feels completely natural. Bilingual in old media and new media, which is a weird skill that gets less useful every year as the old disappears.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1995 brought Windows 95 launching with a $300 million marketing campaign that included the Rolling Stones' 'Start Me Up.' Microsoft bought the world's attention to sell them a Start button. Bill Gates was the richest person alive. The internet was about to change everything, and most people still didn't have email addresses.

eBay launched in 1995. So did Craigslist, Amazon (as a bookstore), and Java. The web was ugly, slow, and revolutionary. It had maybe a few thousand websites total. By the time this cohort was old enough to use it, it had billions and Google existed to find them.

The dot-com bubble burst when this cohort was five, teaching adults that internet companies needed revenue, not just ideas. Twitter launched when they were eleven. The iPhone came out when they were twelve, and everything before it instantly looked prehistoric. This cohort didn't get a smartphone until they were a teenager, which makes them different from Gen Z, who got them in elementary school. They remember the world before everyone had a computer in their pocket.

Facebook opened to the public when this cohort was eleven. By high school, it was how they socialized. By college, it was how they organized and shared. Now it's where relatives post questionable memes and they visit once a year to check birthday notifications. This cohort has watched the entire lifecycle of social media, from novelty to necessity to nuisance.

This generation's relationship with technology is intimate but not unconscious. Learning to type on keyboards, not touchscreens. Remembering downloading music illegally on Napster and Limewire, waiting hours for a single song. Watching technology go from tool to environment. Still able to imagine life without it, which gives perspective younger generations don't have—and which gets less useful every year.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The Oklahoma City bombing killed 168 people when this cohort was four months old, including children in a daycare center. They don't remember it, but it shaped the security state they grew up in. Before that bombing, federal buildings were open. After, they were fortresses. Domestic terrorism was supposed to be unthinkable. This cohort was born into a world learning it wasn't.

This cohort was six when planes hit the towers. First grade. Watching it on a classroom TV, probably, or coming home to parents who didn't know what to say. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started soon after and continued for their entire childhood. This generation has never known an America not at war somewhere.

This cohort was thirteen during the 2008 financial crisis. Old enough to understand that something terrible was happening—adults were losing jobs, losing homes, losing faith in institutions. Old enough to absorb the fear even if they didn't understand credit default swaps. That crisis ended their childhood and shaped their expectations about economic stability forever.

Obama was elected when this cohort was eighteen—the first Black president, a moment that felt historic and hopeful. Trump was elected when they were twenty-one, which felt like history going backward. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world, killing over a million Americans and rewriting the rules of work, school, and daily life.

Sandy Hook happened when this cohort was nineteen. The Parkland students were slightly younger than them—kids who'd grown up with the same active shooter drills, who finally said enough. This cohort understood their anger because they'd lived the same reality of lockdown drills and wondering if their school was next.

This generation has lived through more 'unprecedented' events than any since the Greatest Generation. They've normalized mass shootings, economic collapse, pandemic death. This isn't resilience—it's damage. They've adapted because they had no choice, not because adaptation is a virtue.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

College graduation around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}} meant entering an economy that had technically recovered from 2008 but hadn't fixed any of the underlying problems. Jobs existed. Good jobs with benefits and stability were harder to find. The gig economy was sold as 'flexibility' when it was really 'no benefits and inconsistent income dressed up as entrepreneurship.'

Entering the workforce during the era of open offices, beer fridges, and companies calling themselves 'families' while offering no job security. Probably working somewhere with a ping pong table and a CEO who talks about culture while paying below market rate. Learning that perks are cheaper than salaries.

COVID hit when this cohort was around 25—early career, still establishing themselves. Suddenly working from their bedroom, attending Zoom meetings in business casual tops and pajama bottoms, watching entire industries collapse while tech companies posted record profits. Remote work became permanent, which was great for flexibility and terrible for boundaries. Now always available because home is also work.

This generation job-hops because companies don't reward loyalty anymore. Average tenure is two to three years. Learning that the only way to get a real raise is to leave. Watching colleagues do the same work as them for twice the salary because they negotiated better or got hired when the market was hot. Salary transparency came too late to help them.

Probably dealing with some combination of student debt, rising rent, and the nagging sense that no matter how hard they work, they're falling behind. The math doesn't work. They know it. Employers know it. Everyone pretends not to notice while asking them to demonstrate 'passion' in their cover letters.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Tinder launched when this cohort was seventeen. By the time they were seriously dating as an adult, swipe-based apps were the infrastructure of romance. They might have met partners in person, through friends, at school—but they've definitely also met them through apps. The algorithm is part of their romantic history whether they wanted it or not.

Communication happens primarily through text and DMs. Phone calls feel aggressive—an intrusion requiring explanation. Voicemails are relics that cause anxiety. Entire relationships—flirtation, commitment, conflict, breakup—can happen without ever hearing someone's voice. This is convenient and slightly dystopian, but it's just how things work now.

This generation delayed marriage and kids more than any before. Part of it is financial—weddings cost money they don't have, kids cost more, housing is impossible without inherited wealth or partner income. Part of it is cultural—the pressure to follow a traditional timeline has loosened, which is freeing. Part of it is practical—wanting to be established before adding dependents, but getting established keeps taking longer than promised.

Friendships maintained across distances through group chats and social media. Best friends might live three time zones away. Seeing college roommates once a year but talking to them daily. Geography matters less than it used to, which is good for maintaining connections and bad for building community where one actually lives.

Probably being in a long-distance relationship at some point, made possible by FaceTime and cheap flights. Probably also experiencing the weird loneliness of being hyperconnected online while feeling isolated in person. Connection and loneliness coexist in ways previous generations didn't have to navigate. Still figuring out the balance.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The 2008 financial crisis hit when this cohort was thirteen—old enough to understand that something terrible was happening, young enough for it to shape their entire relationship with money. Watching adults lose jobs, lose houses, lose retirement savings. Learning early that stability is an illusion that can vanish overnight.

Graduating into a job market still recovering from that crash. College cost more than ever. Wages hadn't kept up with inflation in decades. Housing prices climbed while trying to pay off debt and save for a down payment that kept getting further away no matter how much they saved.

This generation's financial anxiety is often dismissed as entitlement by people who bought houses for $60,000 in 1985. The math is different now. A median home costs over $400,000 in most markets. Student loans average $30,000 and often exceed $100,000. Healthcare is tied to employment that can end at any time. The safety net has holes they could drive a truck through.

Probably having a complicated relationship with investing. Seeing the market crash multiple times. Not trusting it. But Social Security might not exist when they retire, so what's the alternative? Gambling on a system they know is rigged because not gambling means losing for certain.

Financial wellness content tells them to skip the latte and invest the difference. This advice is insulting. They're not broke because of lattes. They're broke because wages stagnated while costs exploded, and an entire generation got stuck holding the bag for policy failures that started before they were born. The math doesn't work, and no amount of budgeting apps can fix systemic failure.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation confuses online engagement with real-world action more than they realize. Great at hashtags, inconsistent at voter turnout. Can mobilize a million retweets for a cause and then not show up to the local election that would actually change something. Digital activism feels like activism. The feelings aren't the same as outcomes.

This generation has been so thoroughly trained to cope with dysfunction that they sometimes forget to fight it. Normalizing burnout as a badge of honor. Accepting that healthcare comes from employers who can fire them at will, that education requires decades of debt, that housing is unaffordable. Adapting to a broken system so well that they've stopped demanding it be fixed. Resilience became resignation.

This generation is so steeped in irony that sincerity feels risky. They can't just care about something—they have to care about it with self-aware distance, with acknowledgment of its problems, with protective layers of humor. This makes it hard to advocate for themselves without hedging. It makes earnest enthusiasm feel naive and vulnerable.

This generation's self-deprecation has become its own kind of coping mechanism that doesn't actually help. Joking about being broke, anxious, exhausted—it's relatable, it gets engagement, it builds connection. But it also lets them avoid actually addressing the problems. Laughing about their suffering isn't the same as changing their circumstances.

This generation is so used to being online that they underestimate how much offline life matters. The friends they text daily aren't the same as friends they see weekly. The communities they belong to on social media aren't the same as communities rooted in physical place. They know this intellectually, but the pull of the screen is strong, and real-world connection takes effort the screen doesn't require.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2015-2025): Spending this decade establishing themselves, or trying to. Graduating into a functional but unequal economy—jobs existed, but good jobs with stability were scarce. Probably changing jobs several times, looking for something that paid enough and didn't crush their soul—a combination harder to find than it should be. COVID hit in the middle and reshuffled everything. Learning to work from home, losing social connections they're still rebuilding, maybe moving somewhere cheaper. Ending the 20s with more clarity about what they want and more frustration about what's available.

The 30s (2025-2035): Entering this decade now. This is supposedly when things stabilize—career traction, maybe a long-term partner, possibly kids if that's what they want. But stability feels more precarious than it did for previous generations at this age. Housing is still unaffordable. The job market is volatile. Building a life on shifting ground, which requires constant adjustment. The upside: experienced enough now to know what they're doing. The downside: they know exactly how hard it is.

The 40s (2035-2045): Peak earning years, statistically. Having more authority at work, more confidence in identity, more acceptance of what they can and can't change. Parents will be aging, which brings new responsibilities and costs. If they have kids, they'll be teenagers—which is its own challenge. Being the senior person in rooms where they used to be the youngest. That shift changes how people treat them and what they expect from them.

The 50s (2045-2055): By now, having lived through at least five economic crises, probably another pandemic, and however many 'once in a generation' events actually happen every few years. Thinking about retirement but probably unable to retire at sixty-five. Mentoring people who don't remember a time before smartphones. Finding themselves telling stories about the old days—pre-smartphone, pre-streaming, pre-remote work—and watching younger people's eyes glaze over.

The 60s and beyond (2055+): The world will be unrecognizable from the one this generation was born into. Climate change will have reshaped where and how people live. Technology will have advanced in ways that are hard to predict. Being part of the generation that remembers the transition—from analog to digital, from stable climate to crisis, from economic optimism to permanent precarity. Whether they retire traditionally, work part-time, or rely on family depends on factors still being determined. The one certainty is uncertainty. They've been living with that their whole life.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year. This cohort is part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials. At the tail end of the generation, which puts them in a unique position—old enough to share formative experiences with elder Millennials, young enough to relate to Gen Z.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): More educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer relative to where Gen X was at this age. Gen X came of age during economic expansion. This generation came of age during the aftermath of collapse. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing. Gen X had affordable college. This generation has debt. Gen X had career ladders that went somewhere. This generation has gig work and 'pivot.'

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were this age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. This generation controls 7%. Boomers bought houses on single incomes for two years' salary. This generation can't afford one on two incomes when houses cost eight times the median wage. The lifestyle Boomers took for granted is a fantasy this generation watches in old movies.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): This generation shares more than they differ. Both grew up with the internet. Both entered adulthood during crises. But this generation remembers life before smartphones, however faintly. Gen Z doesn't. This generation had a childhood that was largely offline before middle school. Gen Z was posting on social media before they could read. This generation is slightly more optimistic, or at least remembers a time when optimism made sense.

Life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations. This generation has higher rates of mental health challenges than previous generations at the same age. Anxiety and depression are more common. The world they inherited is harder, and it shows in the data.

But this generation is also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before. They've pushed for equity, destigmatized mental health, and refused to accept what previous generations considered inevitable. This generation inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That matters.

year_events: Windows 95 launched with Rolling Stones fanfare
Toy Story released as first fully CGI film
